conclusion: Solve problem step by step to find tension magnitudes in three ropes.
Object A (5 kg) hanging vertically, Object B (10 kg) on a horizontal surface, Point O connecting three ropes: OA (vertical), OB (horizontal), and OP (at 45° to vertical).
Draw free body diagrams and establish equilibrium equations.
Sum of forces at point O must be zero since the system is at rest.
Define tensions: T₁ = tension in rope OP, T₂ = tension in rope OA, T₃ = tension in rope OB.
Rope OP components: Horizontal component T₁·cos(45°) = T₁·(1/√2) directed to the right, Vertical component T₁·sin(45°) = T₁·(1/√2) directed upward.
Sum of horizontal forces = 0 and sum of vertical forces = 0 for equilibrium at point O.
Horizontal equilibrium equation: T₃ = T₁·cos(45°) = T₁·(1/√2).
Vertical equilibrium equation: T₁·sin(45°) = T₂, T₁·(1/√2) = T₂.
Calculate T₂: T₂ = weight of object A = m₁·g = 5 kg × 10 m/s² = 50 N.
Calculate T₁: T₁ = 50 N × √2 = 50 N × 1.414 = 70.7 N.
Calculate T₃: T₃ = T₁·(1/√2) = 70.7 N × (1/√2) = 50 N.
Verify with weight of object B: T₃ must balance the normal force and weight of B.
Since B is at rest on a horizontal surface, T₃ doesn't need to support B's full weight directly.
Final Answer: Tension in rope OP (T₁) = 70.7 N, Tension in rope OA (T₂) = 50 N, Tension in rope OB (T₃) = 50 N.
